text: Freeman's segregation index (Freeman, 1978) designed capture extent defined groups vertices tend edges vertices group groups.  Formally, index compares observed number -group ties number -group ties expected ties created randomly. Originally index discontinuity network group size configurations characterized higher number -group ties expected random graph, returns 0 (originally described Freeman (1978)). removed truncation returns values betweem -1 1. original Freeman's formulation involves two groups vertices. extended arbitrary number groups. generalization affects way expected number -group edges pure random graph calculated, see Bojanowski & Corten (2014) details. function internally calculates sizes groups vertices supplied attribute vattr. However, possible override specifying "true" type distribution gsizes argument. assumed table (returned table()) numeric vector group sizes. may especially usefull dealing large graphs /large number isolates. object table interpreted mixing matrix. code: if(requireNamespace("igraph", quietly = TRUE)) {  ### artificial EF data x <- ssi(EF3, "race") x   # show it on picture a <- igraph::V(EF3)$race # rescale SSI values to use as shades of gray k <- 1 - scale(x, center=min(x), scale=max(x) - min(x)) plot( EF3, layout=igraph::layout.fruchterman.reingold, vertex.color= gray(k), vertex.label.family="", vertex.shape=c("circle", "square")[a], vertex.label.color=gray( (1-k) > .4 ) )  ### For White's kinship data x <- ssi(WhiteKinship, "gender") x  # plot it a <- match(igraph::V(WhiteKinship)$gender, unique(igraph::V(WhiteKinship)$gender)) k <- 1 - scale(x, center=min(x), scale=max(x) - min(x)) set.seed(1234) plot( WhiteKinship, layout=igraph::layout.fruchterman.reingold, main="Node segregation in White's kinship data", vertex.label.family="", vertex.label=igraph::V(WhiteKinship)$name, vertex.color= gray(k), vertex.shape=c("circle", "csquare")[a], vertex.label.color="black") legend( "topleft", legend=c("Men", "Women"), pch=c(0,1), col=1) }

title: (De)symmetrize square numeric matrix — symmetrize
text: Argument mat square numeric matrix. way made symmetric, asymetric, depends value rule argument. rule "upper" "lower" mat made symmetric copying, respectively, upper triangle onto lower, lower onto upper. value rule specifies values triangle stay returned value. rule "intdiv" -diagonal values distributed approximately equally lower/upper triangles. r computed result, r[,j] equal (x[,j] + x[j,]) \%/\% 2 r[,j] lower triangle. equal (x[,j] + x[j,]) \%/\% 2 + 1 upper triangle. rule "div" -diagonal values distributed equally lower/upper triangles: "intdiv" using normal / division.

title: (De)symmetrize square numeric matrix — symmetrize
code: m <- matrix(1:16, 4, 4)  # copy upper triangle onto lower symmetrically symmetrize(m, "upper") #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] #> [1,]    1    5    9   13 #> [2,]    5    6   10   14 #> [3,]    9   10   11   15 #> [4,]   13   14   15   16  # copy lower triangle onto upper symmetrically symmetrize(m, "lower") #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] #> [1,]    1    2    3    4 #> [2,]    2    6    7    8 #> [3,]    3    7   11   12 #> [4,]    4    8   12   16  # distribute off-diagonal values exactly # r[i,j] = (m[i,j] + m[j,i]) / 2 r1 <- symmetrize(m, "div") r1 #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] #> [1,]  1.0  3.5  6.0  8.5 #> [2,]  3.5  6.0  8.5 11.0 #> [3,]  6.0  8.5 11.0 13.5 #> [4,]  8.5 11.0 13.5 16.0 all.equal(sum(m), sum(r1)) #> [1] TRUE  # distribute off-diagonal values using integer division r2 <- symmetrize(m, "intdiv") r2 #>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4] #> [1,]    1    4    6    9 #> [2,]    3    6    9   11 #> [3,]    6    8   11   14 #> [4,]    8   11   13   16 all.equal(sum(m), sum(r2)) #> [1] TRUE
